content.webTitle: NAACP's six-day, 134-mile Journey for Justice reaches Missouri capital city

fields.headline: NAACP's six-day, 134-mile 'Journey for Justice' reaches Missouri capital city
fields.bodyText: They walked past signs that said “Supporting officer Wilson!” and “Justice was served!” They walked past a man wearing a Ku Klux Klan facemask. They walked past shouts of “Go home!” and the N-word. They walked past grain elevators and $2.37 gas. They walked past a confederate flag with the singer Hank Williams Jr’s head on it. They kept walking. On Friday afternoon, dozens of civil-rights marchers who set out last Saturday from Ferguson, Missouri, arrived in Jefferson City to be joined by hundreds of supporters and deliver a message to the governor: “Hands up, don’t shoot!” The march, organized by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) and called the “Journey for Justice”, took a 134-mile route to culminate in a rally inside the rotunda of the fog-shrouded state capitol. Marchers hoisted umbrellas in the home stretch and carried signs in solidarity with protesters who this week have memorialized Eric Garner, the Staten Island man who died in July after being placed in a chokehold by a police officer. The goal of the march, organizers said, was to call for “reforms of police practice and culture” in Missouri, starting with the replacement of Ferguson police chief Thomas Jackson. The event was planned after the announcement last month that a St Louis county grand jury had decided not to indict Ferguson police officer Darren Wilson in the August killing of an unarmed teen, Michael Brown. While they encountered some ugly scenes, captured by Missourinet journalist Kyle Loethen in a video, the marchers said the experience had been overwhelmingly positive. “What we’ve seen is an extraordinary array of citizens of Missouri who brought us coffee, hot chocolate, sandwiches, refreshments, all along the way without being asked,” NAACP president Cornell William Brooks, who participated in the march, told Loethen. “People who have come and shed tears, who have prayed for us, we’ve seen that. “And we’ve seen a few people who have used the N-word. Who’ve asserted their first-amendment rights with obscenities. And that’s a part of our country, and your rights under the constitution. “All we say to them is, don’t be afraid.” Brooks met Missouri governor Jay Nixon this week. “I was honored to meet with the leadership of our nation’s oldest and largest civil rights organization during the march from Ferguson to the capital this week,” Nixon said in a statement released on Friday. “Through honest dialogue and mutual respect, I’m confident that together we can make meaningful change to address the challenges underlying the events in Ferguson, and build a future of greater peace, opportunity and fairness for all.”
